summary.seg: This manuscript contains a large collection of medical and culinary recipes in Middle English. It also contains a compilation of selections from the instruction manual in Middle English prose and verse that was known as the The Book of Hawking, Hunting, and Blasing of Arms or The Boke of St Albans. This work was first printed by the so-called Schoolmaster Printer at St Albans in 1486. This print includes a treatise on hunting (The manere of huntynge for all manere of bestys) that partly takes the form of an instruction from a 'Dame' to her 'child' and associates it with a 'Dam Julyans Barnes' in its colophon: Explicit Dam Julyans Barnes in her boke of huntyng.. Pepys MS 1047 does not contain materials from this hunting treatise but a selection from additional materials that follow it in the 1486 print of The Boke of St Albans. Although these additional materials are not associated with 'Dam Julyans Barnes', Pepys MS 1047 does refer to her at the end of one of its texts (see f. 5v: 'Explicit Julyan Barne'). This makes Pepys MS 1047 one of two manuscript copies from The Boke of St Albans to ascribe (part of) its contents to this female author; the other manuscript is London, British Library, Harley MS 2340 [see Boffey (2004)].

A copy of the 1486 edition at Cambridge University Library contains annotations by William Burton (1575–1645), historian of Leicestershire, who calls 'Dam Julyans Barnes' the work's author and identifies her as 'Lady Julian Berners', the daughter of Sir James Berners, of Berners Roding, in Essex, and prioress of the Benedictine nunnery of Sopwell, situated a stone's throw away from St Albans. However, there are no sources to corroborate this identification. Moreover, it is unknown what involvement 'Dam Julyans Barnes' had with the work: instead of an author, she may have been an owner, commissioner, or copyist as well [see Boffey (2004)].

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: Precepts in -ly, excerpted from The Book of Hawking, Hunting, and Blasing of Arms [The Boke of St Albans]
msItem.author: (?) Juliana Berners [Bernes, Barnes] (fl. 1460)
msItem.incipit: 1r A ryse erly and serue god devoutly / And the worlde besyly
msItem.explicit: 1r And then slepe suverly / This ffesyk is holi

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the stomach
msItem.incipit: 1v Take sugur and tempyr hit with water yn a dysh then streyn hit through a fayre clene cloth and put ther to the clenest floure that ye can gett
msItem.explicit: 1v And yf hit will not rolle take the more of the sugure. To a pynte of water take an egge

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the toothache
msItem.incipit: 1v-2r Take a baggyd cony and flee here and take oute the knottes and boyle them with brynstone in a littell water then take a glove of lethere and let the glove tille fro your hand to your elbowe and boyle them yn the foresaid water tyll hit be sodyn and then take an vnce or more of assafetida and boyle all to gedere etcaetera

msItem.title: List of collective nouns for animals and humans, excerpted from The Book of Hawking, Hunting, and Blasing of Arms [The Boke of St Albans]
msItem.author: (?) Juliana Berners [Bernes, Barnes] (fl. 1460)
msItem.incipit: 2r A herde of hertes / A herd of all dere / A herde swannys
msItem.explicit: 5v An vncredibelite of cukkoldys / A dysworschip of stottes
msItem.note: One of the entries, giving the collective noun for wives (? 'An vnpacyence of wyfys') on f. 4r has been deleted.
A 15th-century hand has made two additions in darker ink to the list on f. 2r: 'A bevy of quayles' and 'A raskall of Rayles'.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 6r ffor the fflyx a gode medecyn: Take a pynte of rede wyne and a pynte of hote mylke drynke them to gether with .ij. callys of a gose at onys hote of .ij. coppys
msItem.explicit: 6v-7r ffor the colycke and the stone: Take sawmper and take the levys and dry them yn the son or yn a oven on a fayre stone or borde and make powder ther of and vse this poudere when ye be payned take þe powder and put hit in your potage or yn gode ale and ye schall be esyd
msItem.note: The collection includes a non-medical recipes, for protecting clothes against the clothes moth ['To cause mogthys do no hurte to clothes'] (f. 6r).

msItem.title: Method for catching a pike
msItem.rubric: 7r To take a pyke yn the water
msItem.incipit: 7r Take a raw chekyn and clense hit and fyll hit blacke sope and knytt both the endys and pryck hit full of holys and ley hit in þe [crossed out: 'l'] ryver and as sone as he hath etyn hit he wyll comen to land

msItem.title: Collection of culinary recipes
msItem.incipit: 7r Gentyll manly Cokere and copyd of the Sergent to the kyng: To make a stew of flesh yf thy potte be .iiij. gallons do yn a quarte of wyn take fayre befe of the fore loyne or of the hynder loyne and myns itt and take gode capons with all
msItem.explicit: 13r To make water of alym: Take a clene bassyn and put yn water and podour of alym and then set hit yn the hote sonne and
msItem.note: The final recipe is imperfect because the lower portion of the page, containing its ending, has been cut out.

msItem.title: Charm for staunching blood [Flum Jordan]
msItem.rubric: 13v flome Jurdeyn and styntyst the water vpon the stone so stynte thys blode of this man or woman .N. thy seruaunte throw vertu of thy holi name Jhesus and of thy cosyn swete Seynte John and say thys charme .v. tymes with .v. pater nosters In worshipp of the .v. wondys of oure lorde
msItem.incipit: 13v A Charme for the blody flyx: In nomine + patris + et filij + et spiritus + Amen + Stabat Jhesus contra flumen Jordanis et posuit pedem suum et dixit sta aqua per deum te coniuro longinus miles latus domini nostri Jhesu Christi lancia perforauit et continuo exiuit sanguis redempcionis et aqua baptismatis. In nomine Jhesu sta resta + sanguis + In nomine filij + cessa sanguis + In nomine spiritus sancti + vt non exiat amplius sanguis nec gutta ab hoc homine vel ab hac muliere famula uel famulo dei .N. + Sicut credimus in sancta maria vera mater
msItem.note: Full transcription; the charm is missing its beginning because the lower portion of the page, containing its beginning on the recto side, has been cut out.

msItem.title: Collection of culinary recipes in prose
msItem.incipit: 14r Egges in brewte: Take water and seth hit. in the same water breke your egges and cast ther on gyngere pepur and saferon than temper hit vp with swete mylke and boyle hit and then kerve chese and cast ther to small kutte and when hit ys ynowgh serue hit furth
msItem.explicit: 15r To make sauce for a pyke: Take the resette of the pyke and mynse hit small and put hit yn a dysche and take a gode mese of musterd and put of the best and fattest of þe broth a litell in the saucer and schakyd and put hit in the dysche with the resete and put yn a litell vyneager and a lytell vergys ther to and a grete quantite of synamom and sugure and lityll gynger and as ye fele hit with your mowth ye may all way amend hit etcaetera

msItem.title: Collection of culinary recipes in verse
msItem.incipit: 15r Sauce for a mawlerd rosted: Take onyons and mense them wele / Put sum yn thy mawlerd so have þou sele / And mynce mo vnyons I the ken / With the grece of the mawlerd seth hit then / Put ale musterd and hony there to / Boyle all to gedere tyll hit be enowe
msItem.explicit: 16r-16v All maner herbys gode for potage: Take the croppe of rede brere / Rede nettyll croppe and avance also / Prymerose violet to gedere most goo / Letyse betys and borage gode / Towne cresse and cresse that groweth yn flode / Clare savery tyme gode wone / Parcelle worth other herbe many one / All these herbes thow not for sake / But best of prymerose thow schalt take / Rede cole halfe parte of potage ys / ffro June to seynte Jame tyde I wys / Then wynter hys cowrse schall holde / In lent seson porray be bolde
msItem.note: A collection of four recipes for making a sauce for roasted duck, preparing woodcock, and making fritters and a herbs potage; all are associated with the Liber Cure Cocorum a collection of versified recipes in London, British Library, Sloane MS 1986.

msItem.title: Two culinary recipes in prose
msItem.incipit: 16v To dyght a crabe: Take out all yn the crabe and lay hit yn a lityll Wyneagyre take and put a litell rede wyne there to and streyne all trowgh a streynnour take pouder of gynger syamomme and sugure and menge hem all to geder and put hym yn the schell and set hit on the fyre tyll he boyll and when hit ys boyled take hit of an cast pouder of syamomme and sugure apon and serue hit furth
msItem.explicit: 16v To make gode almondys mylke: Take brokyn sugure or for fawte ther of take claryfied hony and put hit into fayre water and set hit on the fyre and boyle hit and skymme hit clene and set hit besyde the fyre and let hit cole and then blanche thy almondys cast them yn a morter and bray them small temper hem vp with þe same water

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 17r A gode medecyn provyd for the reynys of þe backe: Take perspere and herbe yve and bray hit and streyn hit with olde ale or ellys make a posset and drynk the ale fastyng or ellys to bedward and walke hafter the space of an houre thys ys a soffereyn medecyn and a goode
msItem.explicit: 17v ffor the tothe ake: Take a lytill rew and as moche of alym as a bene and a gale that ye make ynke of and breke all thes to gether and put them yn a litell bolster of lynne cloth a .ij. fyngurs length and lay hit a while yn vyneagyr and then lay hit betwene thy gome and thy cheke whan thow goyst to bed

msItem.title: Recipe for the pestilence in prose and verse
msItem.rubric: 17v The most souereyn medycyn for the pestilence concludyd be docturs of fesycke both beyonde the se and yn ynglond also abowte the kyng in late days yn the reyngne of kyng Edward the iiij. þe x yere
msItem.incipit: 18r Take a .ij. spownfull of water and .i. spounfull of vyneagyre and as moche tryacle as a bene and menge all thes togethur and drynke hit fastyng onys yn a weke or .ij. yn a moneth and yff thow be not infecte hit schall preserue the and if thow be infecte hit schall save thy lyffe with goode rewle thys ys provyd and hath saued iij or iiij houndere mens lyvys and wemen and chyldrn yn the cite of Wynchestere in the yere of the kyng above sayde
msItem.explicit: 18r All ys gode but best ys thys / God graunte vs all hevyn blysse - Amen

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 18r A gode medecyn for the syctica and oft provyd: Take a spounefull of the gall of a rede oxe and .ij. spounfull of the water of culerage and .iiij. of his awne water and as moche comyn as half a freynch note and as moche sewet as a small notte
msItem.explicit: 19r To breke a byle: Take grownde Ive and stampe hit and lay the Juse and lefys all on a playstere and lay there to

msItem.title: Culinary recipe to make a stew of herring
msItem.incipit: 19r Sethy heryng be well waterd and take owte the bone and take the myltys and lay them yn a fayre dysh of water
msItem.explicit: 19r and set them on þe fyre and so serue them furth

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 19r for to knytte a senow or a vayne þat is brokyn: Take long wormes when they gendyre and þen stampe them in a vessell and lay to the sore yn maner of a playster
msItem.explicit: 19v-20r To kepe a ffebyll brayn fro dronkeschippe: Take yn the mornyng fastyng .v. levys of bytten and ete them and kepe sum in thy hand to smell ther to all the day among and thow shalt be save

msItem.title: Methods for capturing salmon and pike
msItem.incipit: 20r ffor to take samons: Go to the pole there ye suppose the samon lyeth and make a litill hole hard by the water syde and set yn your candell and take a bryght skowryd basyn and set be hynd the candell and he wyll cum to the candell be kynd of nature
msItem.explicit: 20r for to take a pyke in a poole: Take gutte of a chekyn and make hym clene and take a litell blake sope and put hit yn a litylll of of [sic] the gutte and knyte fast both endys and prycke hit well with a pynne and cast hit into the pole where as the pyke ys and he ete hit he schall turne vp the bely and so dye etcaetera

msItem.title: Two medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 20r-20v Here begynneth gode medecyns and trew for the mygrayne: Take a serten of prymerose levys .ij. partes and the iij parte of yowrthe [crossed out: 'Juse a'] ivys and make juse ther of and take the seke man and lay hym vp ryght and put the juse at his nosetyrle [sic] on the contrary syde that þe grevance ys on and for enythyng þat may fall loke ther go no tyng yn his een
msItem.explicit: 20v for the stone a precious medycyn: Take the levys of warmode and make juse of the same herbe and take hit .iiij. morenynges fastyng a spounfull with olde ale and thys prouyd

msItem.title: Treatise on hunting, hawks and hakwing, excerpted from The Book of Hawking, Hunting, and Blasing of Arms [The Boke of St Albans]
msItem.author: (?) Juliana Berners [Bernes, Barnes] (fl. 1460)
msItem.rubric: 20v To helpe an hawke of dyvers sekenes
msItem.incipit: 20v ffor the ree take the Juse of a dasy and hony and put hit yn the pallet of the mowth that hit may stoppe the holes that ben yn the rofe of þe mowth
msItem.explicit: 22v Thes ben of the swete foote: The fulmard the fychew the grey the ffox the wheysyll the marteron the squyrrell þe waturrate the otur the stote the polkat. And all thes ben gamys of the stynkyng ffoote
msItem.finalRubric: 23r Here endys havkyng with medsysn and castyng / And all that longys to goode hauke kepyng
msItem.note: This treatise comprises various sections from The Book of Hawking, Hunting, and Blasing of Arms [The Boke of St Albans], including sections on the names of dogs, the work of different hounds, hunting terms, resting and mating, the hierarchy of hawks and owners, wines, the ages of a hawk, and hawk's diseases and remedies.

msItem.title: Prognostications based on the day of the week on which Christmas falls
msItem.incipit: 23r That yere that Cristysmas day fallyth on sonday Yemps schal be gode vere wyndy Estas dry vyndege goode and plenty of schepe and of hony pes schall be and olde folkes schall dye
msItem.explicit: 23v That yere that Crystysmas day falleth on a satterday Wyntyr trobyll vere wyndy ffrute travellous olde men schall dye and schepe perysche howses schall byrn

msItem.title: Virtues of the Mass (imperfect)
msItem.rubric: 23v Here ben the medys of the masse
msItem.incipit: 23v To hym that herys his masse and seys the blyssed lord in forme of brede as sayth Seynte Austyn that day a man may not fayll his sustynaunce of his body
msItem.explicit: 23v And yf a man dye that day withowte howsyll the syght of goddys body schall be alowde for hym and stond for his howsyll and as long as thow arte
msItem.note: See McKitterick and Beadle (1992) for other copies.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 1r-23v: Hand with a six-petalled flower ( 120 20 ) in the centre of the folio, comparable to Briquet 10713. This example is dated to 1485.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
Folio i is paper pastedown on the inside of the upper cover; f. iii is a paper pastedown on a blank modern flyleaf at the end of the manuscript.

collation.formula: 124-1: 1 leaf missing between f. 13 and f. 14

supportDesc.condition: The lower portions of f. 13 and f. 14 have been cut out. A vellum strip has been inserted in the gutter at the innermost bifolium (ff. 12v-13r).

layout.seg: Frames occasionally ruled in pencil. Single columns. 20 lines to the page written above and below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single scribe writing in Anglicana formata.

decoNote.p: Recipe headers have been written in red ink.

physDesc.additions: A modern inscription in pencil on f. iii verso ('M.R.J. 5') refers to the catalogue description of M.R. James, which describes the manuscript on pp. 5-6.

binding.p: 17th-century limp binding with Dutch gilt paper covers, featuring dark leaves and birds on a pink and gold ground with, on its front cover a printed heraldic coat of arms with mantling and a helmet, inscribed with the title: 'Miscell. of Reccipes M.S.S. Temp. R. Ed.4.'.
See Nixon, VI (1984), p. xxi and plate 21 ('K 1*')

origin.origDate: Copied in the late 15th century, certainly in or after 1470/1471 (see medical recipe on 17v-18r).

history.provenance: Acquired before 1700 by Samuel Pepys (1633–1703), naval officer and diarist Pepys, Samuel, 1633-1703: listed in the 1700 catalogue as 'A Miscellany of Receipts in Coookery etc. MSS temp. Ed. 4th'. ; no. 6801.82 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697); f. ii verso features an engraving of his portrait with the motto: 'Mens cujusque is est Quisque' and 'Sam. Pepys. Car. et. Iac. Angl. Regib. A. Secretis. Admiraliae' by R. White ['R. W. sculp.'], c. 1690 ; f. iii recto features a paper pastedown with Pepys's bookplate engraved with two anchors and the motto 'Mens cujusque is est Quisque'.

acquisition.p: Acquired by Magdalene College, Cambridge upon the death of John Jackson (d. 1724) Jackson, John, d. 1724 : in his will (The National Archives, PROB 1/9, Will of Samuel Pepys, Codicil, 13th May 1703), Pepys left a bequest of approximately 3000 manuscripts and printed books to Magdalene College and instructed his nephew John Jackson to arrange for this but they only came to the college after Jackson died. Jackson respected the instructions given in the codicil to the will as can be evidenced from Magdalene College Archives A/41/1: an indenture between Anne Jackson, widow and executrix of John Jackson (nephew and residuary legatee of Samuel Pepys), and the Master and Fellows being a deed of covenant as to providing a Library at the College for the reception of the collection of the books and papers bequeathed to the College by Samuel Pepys, 1 June 1724. It is here that the manuscript's current shelfmark 'No 1047' was inscribed in red ink on f. i verso (the inside of the upper cover).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936 A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the College Library of Magdalene College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Library, 1909) and the Catalogue of the Pepys Library at Magdalene College Cambridge, Volume V: Manuscripts, Part I: Medieval, compiled by Rosamond McKitterick and Richard Beadle (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1992), by kind permission of the Boydell Press.

availability.p: Visitors to Magdalene College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Pepys Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Magdalene College: Pepys Library.
